TOCEntry.title: Scope
TOCEntry.content:
This document is the deliverable of the second step of the OpenFlexo Process Mapping Approach. It aims at answering the following question:

What are the objectives of each "Organizational unit"? ... or which processes are implemented by the company - or a subset thereof - to achieve its objectives?

The objectives of each Organizational Unit (subset of the company) involved in the project have been described in the previous step where the objectives were viewed from an organisational point of view.

This second step maps these objectives on a often different operational view. We are concerned here with identifying the processes that are implemented to achieve these objectives:

  • identify and document the macro-processes, i.e., a high level decomposition of activities used by one organizational unit, a group of processes without reality within an organization unit.
  • identify and documents the processes, i.e. a low level decomposition of correlated activities that transform input elements into output elements and that are executed by an organization unit.
  • identify and documents the roles, i.e. a set of reponsabilities given to one or several actors within the course of the process. A role should not be confused with neither an actor nor a position. An actor is an individual asuming one or several roles. A position is an administrative concept associated with a contract between an actor and an organization unit.

Here usually follows a general description of the whole project process context.

TOCEntry.title: Concepts
TOCEntry.content:
The macro-process decomposition is performed by partioning the objectives associated with the organizational units in a more operational way. Macro-processes are indeed associated with several of those objectives while a process is associated with only one. Each macro-process leads to another macro-procss or a set of processes. Processes can also have subprocesses.

A macro-process is described as follows:

  • NAME: identifies the macro-process in a unique way. Best practice: Macro-process name usually is a substantive.
  • DESCRIPTION: a short text explaining what the macro-process does.
  • OBJECTIVES the list of the organization unit objectives the realization of which is taken care of by its macro-processes.
  • DEPENDENCIES (Optional): List of dependencies between macro-processes, i.e a dependancy is defined as an existing  « link » between two macro-processes specifying that the execution of one is required by the executionof the other.

A process is described as follows:

  • NAME: Identifies the process in a unique way. Best practice: always use an infinitive verb - noun (e.g. Open customer account, …) because the process express the notion of execution.
  • DESCRIPTION: Text describing what the process does with additional field examples to clarifying the explanation. At this point we focus on WHAT the process  does and not too much on WHO neither on HOW the process works. These aspects will be the core of the next methodological step. It is also often very usefull to describe process  PRE and POST-CONDITIONS, i.e.
    • Pre-conditions are the conditions that need to be verified in order to fire the execution.
    • Post-conditions describe the situation that should be reached after the process execution.
  • Pre-conditions are the conditions that need to be verified in order to fire the execution. Post-conditions describe the situation that should be reached after the process execution.
  • OBJECTIVES: describe the Organizational unit objectives whose realization are taken care of by this processes.

An organizational unit - in addition to its title - can be described using the following information:

  • NAME: Identifies the organizational units in a unique way. Best practice: al
  • MISSION: a summary description of the rationale of the unit
  • OBJECTIVES: goals that the unit must achieve in a given period of time.

A role is a set of responsabilities (e.g. decide, execute, ...) given to one or several actors working in the process.
Remarks:
  • ROLE and ACTOR should not be confused:
    • An actor is an individual often playing several roles.
    • A role can be played by one or several actors.
  • ROLE  and POSITION  should not be confused either:
    • A POSITION is an administrative concept, corresponding to a work contract between an organization unit and the employee.

Modeling best practices for the second step

The Macro-Processes and Processes documentation will be automatically generated in the next subsection "Macro-Process and ¨Processes" from the associated macro-process and process tree. TThis tree of macro-processes and processes must be defined in the OpenFlexo  workflow editor. A macro-process can be seen as a folder of processes.

Usually top macro-processes are used to categorize the processes as Transversal, Vertical, Reusable, ...

This second step table of content must be associated with the "User Manuel" documentation target.

Macro-processes and processes both use the following OpenFlexo fields for defining the previously defined attributes:

  • a name used as the NAME
  • a general description combined with the User Manual target description used as the DESCRIPTION
  • the Objectives target description used as DESCRIPTION.

Organizational units and Roles sections are automatically generated in the subsection "Organization Units and Roles" from the OpenFlexo  workflow editor role perspective. Arrows should go from organization units to roles.

Generic roles (union of roles associated in different organizational units) are often defined when reusable process are used.

Organisation units and roles attributes are both encode in OpenFlexo  as follows:

  • DESCRIPTION  is a combination of the general and "User Manual" target description.
  • OBJECTIVES are specified in the "Objectives" target description.
